Description: Rim and wall fragment of North Ionian black-figured pottery bowl; extremely worn. On the exterior of the rim, chequerboard frieze; below, a lion to left, looking back; behind him a floral complex; further chequerboard below, above a lotus and bud frieze; added red on neck and belly of lion, and on lotus. Interior glazed with narrow red bands. The bowl was almost certainly slipped inside and out. Glazet fired to light red (10 R 6/6).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Venit: 'Checkers are also found decorating lips of Clazomenian vessels; see R.M. Cook, "A list of Clazomenian Pottery", BSA 47 (1952), p.144, and compare Berlin 4530 from Benha (Samos 6.1, pl.127 no.919) and its companion piece from Mendes (K.L. Wilson, "Mendes: Preliminary Report on the 1979 and 1980 Seasons", Malibu, 1982, pl.25 fig.1). A bowl from Naukratis, Boston 88.1033 (Fairbanks pl.33, 315; Samos 6.1, pl.125 no.1018), also has a band of checkers on the exterior and Cook cites as "an abnormal [Clazomenian] oinochoe" a vessel with a band of "five chequers...around the top of its belly" ("List of Clazomenian Pottery", p.144). This similarity of motif connects the fragment in Alexandria with the North Ionian region and further strengthens the connection of Late Wild Goat incised ware with that area.'
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 22, no. 73 pl. 21)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.156)
